results.title: The In crowd
results.creator_credit: Force Ten, Orion Pictures Corporation, Keith Rubinstein, Lawrence Konner and Mark Rosenthal
results.brief_description: Its 1965, and rock’n’roll has ricocheted around the world. Nowhere is the music more popular than Philadelphia, where smooth-talking Perry Parker (Joe Pantoliano) hosts the city’s hottest TV show “Dance Party”. The dancing fever has also infected the suburbs where Del Green (Donovan Leitch), a high school senior, spends most of his time spinning, twisting and daydreaming of Vicky (Jennifer Runyon), “Dance Party’s” reigning teen goddess. On a dare Del foregoes his college entrance exam, auditions for the show, is chosen and becomes an instant success. Del and Vicky become “Dance Party’s” hottest new couple. To the beat of 60s rock’n’roll, and against a steamy backdrop of fancy footwork and raw competition, their make-believe romance becomes a doomed off-stage love affair.

results.title: The Impressionists
results.creator_credit: International Film Bureau, Egons Tomsons and George Barford
results.brief_description: An explanation of the impressionist style and spirit is given. The film then follows chronologically, through the works of Monet, Manet, Pissarro, Sisley, Renoir and Degas, illustrating differences and similarities between them. Brushwork and style is examined.

results.title: The Impressionable years: American children and the public library
results.creator_credit: United States Information Service and Peter Elgar
results.brief_description: Describes a young girl’s first experience of the children’s room of the New York Public Library. Evokes in an imaginative way the pleasures, satisfactions and companionship children can find in reading. Shows story hours, simple reference work and borrowing routines. Emphasises the child’s freedom of choice and the way in which the library is scaled to their requirements. Narrated by Henry Fonda.

results.title: The Impossible takes a little longer
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Kathleen Shannon, Barbara Janes and Anne Henderson
results.brief_description: The Impossible Takes a Little Longer documents the work and personal lives of five physically disabled women. It shows how they are coping with the problems they share with all women, the problems they share with other disabled women and those unique to their particular circumstances. The film affirms that disabled women can lead full and productive lives as workers, as mothers and as valued community members. It informs both disabled women and the able-bodied about the possibilities of adaptations in the workplace, the use of technological aids and the need for support systems if disabled women are to have satisfying and productive lives. The Impossible Takes a Little Longer undermines the stereotypes and prejudices that further hinder a large segment of our population.

results.title: The Impossible dream
results.creator_credit: Kratky Film, Peter Hollander and Dagmar Doubkova
results.brief_description: An animated film without narration about a family which operates within traditional stereotyped roles where the woman is mother, housekeeper and wage earner while the man is wage earner only. Shows how the children imitate their parents in these sex roles. A useful discussion starter in the area of sex role stereotyping. Suitable for middle and upper primary and secondary levels.

results.title: The Importance of making notes
results.brief_description: Discusses the important skills of note-taking, showing how to take good notes in oral instruction periods and during reading. Explains how to determine the key ideas for notes; describes the kinds of information which should be taken down verbatim, and points out when notes should not be taken at all.

results.title: The Importance of keeping perfectly still
results.creator_credit: Kookaburra Productions, Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School, Mark Ruse and Michael Pattinson
results.brief_description: Concerns a young man apprenticed to a high society photographer at the turn of the 19th century. When his boss receives a vice regal appointment to photograph the Governor’s family, he cannot handle the strain of this and a love affair at the same time. His girlfriend insists that she must have a ‘sign’ from heaven before a marriage can take place. Cast includes Liddy Clark, Frederick Parslow, Peter Sardi, Frank Thring, Frank Wilson.

results.title: The Importance of food safety
results.brief_description: This video is about how to safely handle and prepare food for public consumption. It is aimed at people who prepare food in the hospitality industry and other food handling professions, but contains useful tips to keep in mind when preparing food in the home. Discusses bacteria and how to lessen its effects, storage temperatures and conditions for food, both raw and cooked, freezing, thawing and cooking of food, delivery of food and how to lessen the likelihood of illness from improperly prepared food. Includes a questionnaire to test knowledge of content of video.

Includes a questionnaire to test knowledge of content of video.

results.title: The Importance of flow in furrow irrigation
results.brief_description: Shows how the three aims of controlled irrigation can be achieved in furrow irrigation by putting the “correct flow” down the furrows so as to obtain even distribution of the water over the whole area and down to the depth of the root zone. The various factors which determine “correct flow” are briefly considered and finally the method whereby it may be obtained and checked is outlined.

results.title: The Importance of being earnest [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Rank Film Productions, Javelin, Two Cities Films, Teddy Baird and Anthony Asquith
results.brief_description: Film adaptation of Oscar Wilde’s brilliant play “The Importance of being earnest” (1895), adapted and directed for the screen by Anthony Asquith, is probably the best-known comedy of manners in the world. Jack Worthing and Algernon Moncrieff are friends, both bachelors operating in English society hoping to find love in a proper match. Each man has spun lies about a fake identity in order to achieve romance with Gwendolyn Fairfax and Cecily Cardew, respectively. When the two couples meet up at Cecily’s place of residence, their lies unfurl and the true selves of both are revealed. Wilde’s last play is a satire on English society and manners, wonderfully sending up the portentousness and pomposity of the upper classes. Two particularly memorable characters are the boorish snob Lady Bracknell and the dithering governess Miss Prism (the latter played with import here by Margaret Rutherford). Asquith never quite transcends the script’s theatrical origins, but does successfully recreate the cadence and spirit of Wilde’s sardonic, barbed wit.
